_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN
MPM Silicones, LLC
WATERFORD, NY

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY


Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies:

The following information can be found in Section A.1.0 of the MPM Silicones, LLC, Waterford Safety Manual, which is fully endorsed by facility managers.

ENVIRONMENTAL, HEALTH AND SAFETY (EHS) POLICY 
    
MPM Silicones, LLC is committed to achieving environmental, health and safety (EHS) excellence. This is the responsibility of both management and employees in all functions of the business. We strive to provide a safe and healthy working atmosphere and to avoid adverse impact to the environment and communities in which we do business. Our EHS process is expected to combine clear leadership by management, the participation of all employees and functions and the use of appropriate technology in developing, and distributing MPM Silicones products and services. 

We will utilize Process Hazard Analysis (PHA), Incident Investigation, Management of Change (MOC), pre-start-up safety review (PSSR), process safety information (PSI) and Training involvement processes in our Process Safety Management Program.  All employees have access to and/or are provided process safety information.  We actively involve employees in the development and implementation of Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures and Training, and other elements of the PSM Standard (OSHA 1910.119).  It is recognized that employees who are responsible for operating processes are the key resource in a successful Process Safety Program. 

We are accomplishing the above goals through:

* Making a clear and visible statement of our EHS Policy.

* Defining responsibilities, accountability, recognition and disciplinary actions.

* Exercising both management and employee involvement in EHS.

* By providing appropriate EHS training to all employees.   

* Performing on-going evaluations and revisions to EHS processes for lasting effectiveness and continuous improvement.

* Esta

blishing procedures to effectively recognize, evaluate and control EHS hazards.

* Using Six Sigma tools to help drive EHS performance excellence. 

At MPM Silicones, we realize that our most valued assets are our employees. Both management and employees must consider themselves a team, working together to accomplish the common goal of a safe, healthful and environmentally sound workplace.

Description of facility and regulated substances:

MPM Silicones, LLC, (Momentive) Waterford, located at 260 Hudson River Road in Saratoga County, New York, is a specialty chemical manufacturing facility that produces silicone intermediates and products.  This manufacturing facility is located on an 800-acre site adjacent to the Hudson River, where it has been in operation since 1947.  Currently, the facility has approximately 985 employees.  The facility uses an estimated 400 chemicals to produce over 1,000 intermediate products using approximately 90 different batch processes.  Through the conversion of silicon metal to silicone fluids and gums, Momentive supplies constituents that are used in the manufacture of over 2,000 consumer and industrial products, including oils, lubricants, adhesives, coatings, gums, sealants and rubber.

The MPM Silicones, LLC Waterford Facility uses eight chemicals that are regulated under EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP) in quantities above the reporting threshold.  Five of these are from the family of chemicals known as chlorosilanes.  These include methyltrichlorosilane, dimethyldichlorosilane, trimethylchlorosilane (regulated as toxic substances), tetramethylsilane and trichlorosilane (regulated as a flammable substances).  Other regulated toxic chemicals include methyl chloride and hydrochloric acid.  Hydrogen is the other flammable material physically present at the facility that is regulated by the RMP regulation.  Although the hydrogen storage is part of a stationary source not owned or operated by Momentive, Momentive carried out an offs

system. There were no off site impacts or evacuations, however there was $50,000 of on-site property damage. In an effort to prevent this type of event from happening in the future, process operating procedures were modified and certain process control devices involved in the incident were physically relocated on the system.

The Emergency Response Program:

The Waterford, New York site maintains a written emergency response program designed to protect workers, the public, and the environment in the event of a major accidental release.  As part of this program, we have developed and implemented written programs to train all of our employees in the proper response to an incident.  We have also developed and trained more extensively a smaller number of employees to act as an emergency brigade to provide more expertise in responding to more significant events both on and off site.  We have equipped this brigade with equipment needed to respond to emergencies, both on-site and off-site.  This equipment includes three fire trucks, two ambulances, and two HAZMAT vehicles.  Our trained fire brigade and medical and chemical response teams work closely with area hospitals, industries and other emergency response organizations in the Capital Region.  

We have mutual aid agreements with the emergency response organizations in the Town of Waterford, the Towns of Halfmoon and Saratoga, and Rensselaer, Washington and Albany counties to insure that adequate resources are available to respond on-site and off-site to chemical emergencies.  As a result of the agreements, the MPM Silicones, LLC emergency brigade has responded to many non-MPM Silicones, LLC off-site chemical and other emergencies.  Recent emergency training drills, organized and directed by the MPM Silicones, LLC emergency brigade, have included:
* A chemical release from a leaking MeCl railcar in 2009.
* Boom deployment for an oil sheen on the Hudson River involving one of our emergency response contractors, Clean Ha

rbors.

Ongoing training exercises are important to the MPM Silicones, LLC emergency response organization and help prepare our partners in the community for emergency response in the unlikely event of a major industrial accident. 

MPM Silicones, LLC personnel have helped develop emergency preparedness plans for local communities.  In addition, they are members of local emergency planning and community emergency response groups.  We have provided training and equipment to our mutual aid partners. As consistent with the Saratoga County Emergency Plan, MPM will work through the Waterford Police and Saratoga Emergency Management Office to communicate any appropriate actions to be taken by the public in the event of a chemical emergency.

Planned changes to improve safety:

The MPM Silicones, LLC Waterford facility has achieved recognition as an OSHA Voluntary Protection Program (VPP) Star site.  VPP status is a way for OSHA to recognize facilities that go above and beyond compliance with safety regulations.  Only approximately 0.03% of work sites in the country have achieved VPP status.  

The VPP requires a commitment by the facility to continuous safety improvement.  MPM Silicones, LLC is committed to the VPP and is therefore continuously striving to improve the safety of the Waterford facility.

The facility has several projects and programs planned for the near future to improve our safety performance.  These include:
* Installation of safety swing gates on all appropriate fixed industrial ladders
* Creation of hands-on training stations for confined space entry and grounding and bonding, and
* Developed a comprehensive safety plan that will reduce or injuries by more then 20% in 2010.
